description: Borrowed from French garde-robe, from garder (“to keep”) + robe (“robe, dress”). Doublet of wardrobe.

entries.meaning: (historical) A lavatory, especially in a castle and built into the outer wall, with vent directly over the moat or midden.
examples: He splashed some tepid water on his face from the basin beside his bed and took his time squatting in the garderobe, the night air cold on his bare skin.
